Hi John,

I join that discussion because testing the good behaviour of some threads
(which invoked the wait() and notify() methods) has been a quest in a very
efficient GUI we developed in our company.
I would stress the fact that having a Test framework (like JUnit) in many
circumstances is a real plus for a lot of reasons; many times you do not
have all the thread experencied programmers you need in order to perform a
code inspection (though we make use of Fagan Inspection as we moving to CMM
lev. 3) and, above all, having a consolidated set of tests to be run every
once you need in order to check that everything does what it's expected to
do makes you save a lot of time (=money).
Last, but not least, also in the very deep and careful code inspection some
ungraceful thread behaviours should be missed by the most experienced thread
programmers while such unwanted behaviour should (though it's always not a
must) be highlighted by exercising the piece of code itself.

Anyway, formal proof is the latest word... but that's another story..

Bye
Luca Sfarzo
TRS Neapolis

> We've a couple of places where we have threads waiting for eachother using

..cut...
> Or
> does anyone have a reference to an article or web where this test may be
> described in a generic way or with an example?

..cut..

However, the inherent indeterminism requires a lot of effort to come up with
such a test suite. In most situations it's probably more effective to  have
the multi-threaded code reviewed by expeprienced "thread programmers". Even
better: Use threading libraries (eg the one described in Doug Lea's seminal
work "Concurrent Programming in Java")  which hide most of the intricacies
of
threaded programming.

Johannes
